{{cpp/title|n=literals::chrono_literals::|operator""s}}
{{cpp/chrono/duration/navbar}}
{{dcl begin}}
{{dcl header|chrono}}
{{dcl|num=1|since=c++14|
constexpr std::chrono::seconds
    operator""s( unsigned long long secs );
}}
{{dcl|num=2|since=c++14|
constexpr std::chrono::duration&lt;/*unspecified*/&gt;
    operator""s( long double secs );
}}
{{dcl end}}

Forms a {{lc|std::chrono::duration}} literal representing seconds.

@1@ Integer literal, returns exactly {{c|std::chrono::seconds(secs)}}.
@2@ Floating-point literal, returns a floating-point duration equivalent to {{lc|std::chrono::seconds}}.

===Parameters===
{{par begin}}
{{par|secs|the number of seconds}}
{{par end}}

===Return value===
The {{lc|std::chrono::duration}} literal.

===Possible implementation===
{{eq fun
|1=
constexpr std::chrono::seconds operator""s(unsigned long long s)
{
    return std::chrono::seconds(s);
}
constexpr std::chrono::duration&lt;long double&gt; operator""s(long double s)
{
    return std::chrono::duration&lt;long double&gt;(s);
}
}}

===Notes===
{{cpp/chrono/chrono_literals_namespace}}

{{lc|std::string}} also defines {{c/core|operator""s}}, to represent literal objects of type {{tt|std::string}}, but it is a string literal: {{c|10s}} is ten seconds, but {{c|"10"s}} is a two-character string.

===Example===
{{example
|code=
#include &lt;chrono&gt;
#include &lt;iostream&gt;

int main()
{
    using namespace std::chrono_literals;

    std::chrono::seconds halfmin = 30s;
    std::cout &lt;&lt; "Half a minute is " &lt;&lt; halfmin.count() &lt;&lt; " seconds"
        " (" &lt;&lt; halfmin &lt;&lt; ").\n"
        "A minute and a second is " &lt;&lt; (1min + 1s).count() &lt;&lt; " seconds.\n";

    std::chrono::duration moment = 0.1s;
    std::cout &lt;&lt; "A moment is " &lt;&lt; moment.count() &lt;&lt; " seconds"
        " (" &lt;&lt; moment &lt;&lt; ").\n"
        "And thrice as much is " &lt;&lt; (moment + 0.2s).count() &lt;&lt; " seconds.\n";
}
|output=
Half a minute is 30 seconds (30s).
A minute and a second is 61 seconds.
A moment is 0.1 seconds (0.1s).
And thrice as much is 0.3 seconds.
}}
